channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.dc:creator: David Estcourt
item.description: One man is dead and the other in critical condition after being rushed to hospital by a friend in Melbourne's north.
item.title: One man dead and one critical as homicide squad investigates

item.description: In the first of two addresses for US graduates, former president Barack Obama has says some of his country's leaders are not even pretending to be in charge.
item.title: Obama tells graduates the coronavirus pandemic has torn back the curtain on US government

item.description: Willard spent three seasons on Everybody Loves Raymond, earning three Emmy Award nominations.
item.title: Fred Willard, master comic who starred in Everybody Loves Raymond, dead at 86

item.dc:creator: Lucy Cormack
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: Coronavirus updates LIVE: Morrison government locks in COVID-19 independent review with EU support as global cases top 4.5 million, Australian death toll at 98

item.description: Follow our rolling coverage.
item.title: Tablet interactive: Coronavirus outbreak

item.dc:creator: Zach Hope
item.description: Rich lister Larry Kestelman has clawed back millions from investors who have failed to pay up for one of Melbourne's most glittering developments.
item.title: Buyers fail to pay up in glittering South Yarra mega development

item.dc:creator: Peter FitzSimons
item.description: COVID-19 has claimed the mayor of a French town long associated with Australia.
item.title: Farewell to a good friend taken by coronavirus

item.dc:creator: Steven Hamilton
item.description: The last thing anyone needs is to have the government pull the rug out from under them.
item.title: Scheme is flawed but JobKeeper promises need to be honoured

item.dc:creator: Wendy Tuohy
item.description: Two large surveys are investigating how we are sharing the load at home during isolation.
item.title: COVID and domestic dissonance: 'The aim is equality with your wife – not your dad'

item.dc:creator: The Herald's View
item.description: Since Scott Morrison effectively closed our borders on March 20, we have been left with a tableau of Australian life in the Year 2020. Frozen in time. And we have a rare opportunity to stand back and study exactly how we are constituted.
item.title: Coronavirus pandemic gives us a chance to take stock on immigration

item.description: I have received messages from friends regarding Australians being confined to their homes and how they might begin to understand refugees' incarceration.
item.title: As I learn to live in freedom, Australia is still tormenting refugees

item.description: The pandemic has only served to reinforce deep inequities in the education system.
item.title: Every student deserves a fair go

item.dc:creator: Tony Wright
item.description: Victoria and NSW are now sharply divided about what should be done to control wild horse numbers in alpine regions.
item.title: All the pretty horses and all the damage done

item.dc:creator: Wendy Tuohy
item.description: The departure of two public figures who have made comments involving violence against women could be viewed as a time for advocates to rejoice, but it's not.
item.title: Maybe mocking violence against women isn't so acceptable after all

item.dc:creator: Danny Weidler
item.description: Greg Inglis has opened up about his own mental health issues in a bid to address some of the disgraceful commentary surrounding James Roberts’ stint in rehab.
item.title: 'He should be proud’: Message to Roberts as Inglis steps up for a mate in need

item.dc:creator: Adrian Proszenko
item.description: The NRL has overhauled the refereeing ranks. Now attention has turned to transforming how the bunker will be used.
item.title: Bunker down: Players drive bold plan to reduce reliance on video referee

item.description: Is there any future in swiping right when you are exposed to a tirade of abuse?
item.title: Online dating: When the language of 'love' is toxic

item.dc:creator: Benjamin Preiss
item.description: The hospitality sector could begin a staged reopening with testing data buoying government hopes that community transmission is low.
item.title: Pubs, restaurants and cafes set to reopen within weeks

item.dc:creator: David Estcourt
item.description: Victorians flocked to parks and beaches to enjoy new freedoms on the first weekend after lockdown rules were eased.
item.title: 'Freedom day' sees Melburnians cautiously bask in May sun as restrictions ease

item.dc:creator: Jordan Baker
item.description: As schools prepare to welcome students full time by month's end, there are concerns about how the transport network will cope
item.title: Full-time school to put extra pressure on transport, roads

item.dc:creator: Alexandra Smith
item.description: Deputy Premier says he still has some fight left in him after his bruising byelection stoush with Andrew Constance.
item.title: 'I was terrified': Barilaro's epiphany could bring a change of heart

item.dc:creator: Lucy Manly
item.description: The closure of bricks and mortar stores has meant a wave of new clients and first-time buyers have started dipping their toes in the auction world.
item.title: Virtual paddles stay raised as art auction houses report steady sales

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: The cotton industry is using the recent big rains in major inland catchments to recover from its worst crop in 40 years.
item.title: Cotton 'starts firing' after rain and river flows transform a dustbowl

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: Farmers have been plunged into uncertainty by China’s foreign investment strategy as its hunger for Australian food wanes.
item.title: Farmer turmoil as China's hunger for Australia wanes

item.dc:creator: Adam Carey
item.description: Poppy Johnston will return to class on May 26, part of the first wave of students to go back after weeks of remote learning. She isn’t looking forward to it.
item.title: School 'refusers' thriving in remote learning environment

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: Employers will have to eliminate numerous health hazards to comply with the government's COVIDsafe plan for workplaces.
item.title: 'Hot desking is dead': why workers can refuse to return to the office

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: A study by UNICEF has found the coronavirus lockdown is damaging the wellbeing of Australian teenagers, with less than half saying they are coping well.
item.title: Teenage girls more stressed and anxious under lockdown than boys

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: Demand for childcare has bounced back to 60 per cent as economic activity ramps up and parents return to work.
item.title: Tehan flags end to free childcare as parents return to work

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: The $130 billion JobKeeper program is a windfall for low and medium income earners, especially couples and single parents.
item.title: The 'weird' windfalls and losses under JobKeeper

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: This downturn is "overwhelmingly hurting" young Australians and women.
item.title: The uneven pain of the coronavirus downturn

item.dc:creator: Lucy Manly
item.description: They keep a low profile when attending exclusive parties and social soirees, rarely appearing in the social pages or – heaven forbid – gossip columns.
item.title: The millionaire kids keeping wealth below the radar

item.dc:creator: Jacqueline Maley
item.description: COVID can't cover for everything. Still the government must answer for sports rorts, a grab for ASIO powers and what might become of its economic agenda.
item.title: The political art of not wasting a crisis, or getting wasted by it

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: It's been a year since Scott Morrison won a 'miracle' victory at the 2019 federal election. Australia has changed dramatically since then.
item.title: One year on: how the Morrison government has performed

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: "They're beating their chest about putting in a bid for Virgin, yet they've got their border closed. It's ridiculous."
item.title: Sydney 'dreary', Queensland 'ridiculous': Ministers trade barbs over border closure

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: A war of words has erupted between councillors over the redevelopment of the Ryde Civic Centre.
item.title: 'Vanity project': Ryde Council divided over mayor's civic centre plans

item.dc:creator: Helen Pitt
item.description: In the COVID-19 era, educators overseas are finding new ways for students to transition out of high school. We need to consider the options.
item.title: For students and teachers' sake, it's time to stop the 2020 HSC exams

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: The NSW Opposition has joined calls for public libraries to reopen after they were left out of the state government's relaxation of restrictions.
item.title: 'It's a great mystery': calls for public libraries to reopen in NSW

item.dc:creator: Melissa Singer
item.description: Lipstick and other testers have been 'red carded' because of COVID-19 but there is a silver lining, according to experts.
item.title: The future of shopping: fitting rooms, beauty testers face COVID axe

item.dc:creator: Riley Wilson
item.description: Tired of scrolling through streaming options? Turn your attention to these inspiring online locations for a creativity hit.
item.title: Five creative sites to inspire your next DIY project

item.dc:creator: Alexandra Smith
item.description: Some National Party members say Deputy Premier John Barilaro is not 'a true Nat' but others say he has been very effective.
item.title: 'The rot set in with greyhounds': Can the NSW Nationals survive?

item.dc:creator: Jennifer Duke
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of customers at Australia's big four banks have deferred mortgage repayments on $150 billion of home loans during the coronavirus pandemic shutdowns.
item.title: Banks, regulators discuss help for jobless once mortgage freeze ends

item.dc:creator: Natassia Chrysanthos
item.description: The tutoring industry has taken a massive hit as centres suspend face-to-face teaching and parents pause discretionary spending during the economic downturn.
item.title: Tutoring industry slumps, with least-coached cohort to take next tests

item.dc:creator: Andrew Hornery
item.description: I hate to think how many scandals remained unearthed in 2020 because there was no opportunity to gossip about them.
item.title: RIP the A-list party – and the gossip we'll never know

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: The adaptation of Sally Rooney's "great Millennial novel" has won legions of new fans, but some people just can't understand the hype.
item.title: Sex sells: Why we love (and loathe) Normal People

item.dc:creator: Jennifer Duke
item.description: Most banks and economists are predicting double-digit falls in house prices. But when it comes to the recovery, views differ.
item.title: Safe as houses? How COVID-19 will hit home buyers and builders

item.dc:creator: Melissa Singer
item.description: Going back to the office may be a little while off but it isn't too soon to plan what Monday-to-Friday style might look like in the future.
item.title: Get ready to dress in 'biz-leisure' for the post-pandemic workplace

item.dc:creator: Jamila Rizvi
item.description: #1 Adoration: She is making her home in a newly cleaned passata jar and seems mostly content. I text mates to discuss an appropriate name.
item.title: The 10 stages of sourdough starter grief

item.description: Ambitious opposition planning spokesman Liberal Tim Smith would knock over his grandmother to get to a microphone.
item.title: Victorian Libs tearing themselves apart as Andrews soars

item.dc:creator: Nick Miller
item.description: Victorian Opera's Cinderella will go to the ball, but only after all the doorknobs are disinfected.
item.title: It's a socially distant Cinderella story for opera singers back at work

item.description: Having more options just makes us more stressed and less happy. And at a time when we’re already very stressed and often quite unhappy, we don’t need the telly adding to our grief.
item.title: When we're stressed, sometimes we just want to watch what's on
